subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Which lexical set is the second vowel of _because_ in?
msgSnippet: ... But surely any low-content with a vowel frem the checked group (KIT, DRESS, TRAP, FOOT, STRUT, LOT) can get a de-stressed form with schwa?  And surely
messageBody:
On 2009-01-07 peter_r_guinness wrote:
> However there have been a few other words for which it
> seems clear
> enough to me that they are of a certain lexical set but
> that it has an
> unusual pronunciation in some accent with respect to its
> set. eg: I
> would say that _of_ is a LOT set since in RP it is /Qv/
> and GA has a
> pronunciation /A:v/ (LOT typically has RP-/Q/ and
> GA-/A/): but there
> is also a very common (apparently the most common GA
> according to
> Longman's) GA pronunciation /Vv/. LOT doesn't not
> normally have a /V/
> option for GA- but in this case I would say that it is
> still a LOT
> word but with one extra unusual pronunciation. The word
> _from_ is
> very similar: RP->/frQm/, GA->/frVm, frQm/.

But surely any 'low-content' with a vowel frem the 'checked'
group (KIT, DRESS, TRAP, FOOT, STRUT, LOT) can get a
de-stressed form with schwa? And surely these words should
be spellad as if stressed even when they aren't? To be sure
both _him_ and _them_ can become /Vm/ when fully unstressed,
but I don't think anybody would want to spell them like
that. Where a problem may arise is when such de-stressed
forms get a restressed form with /V/, but as long as the old
pre-destressing form also remain in use we should spell
according to that.

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
"C'est en vain que nos Josués littéraires crient
à la langue de s'arrêter; les langues ni le soleil
ne s'arrêtent plus. Le jour où elles se *fixent*,
c'est qu'elles meurent." (Victor Hugo)
